Award.AwardTitle: FSML Improvements: Provision of a molecular ecology laboratory at the Shannon Point Marine Center
Award.AbstractNarration:
Western Washington University is awarded a grant for is the development of a molecular ecology laboratory at the The Shannon Point Marine Center (SPMC). The lab currently hosts extensive ecological research programs including field ecology, oceanographic research, experimental ecology, chemical and physiological ecology. The lab will extend existing research capacity to molecular mechanisms in marine organisms. Scientists at SPMC will be able to link environment to physiology and molecular mechanisms and to link phylogeny and evolutionary history to ecological function in the Salish Sea and other ocean systems. Accordingly, SPMC proposes to purchase a benchtop genome sequencer whose specifications will assure affordability, flexibility and provide for the rapid turnaround of results that can support short term projects that involve student research as well as the longer term needs of faculty. Equipment to provide for on-site sample preparation and documentation as well as data storage and analysis will be obtained to satisfy the requirements of resident and visiting scientists and students.

Maintaining effective facilities to support both training of the next generation of marine science professionals and research in the marine environment is essential to program success, particularly given that many students visiting SPMC come from institutions that have no access to marine environments. SPMC trains faculty from local community colleges in incorporating marine science into the curricula of introductory courses, populated by students who typically will not pursue degrees in marine science or science of any discipline. Workshops will incorporate the use of molecular tools in marine science as part of the training. SPMC's Public Education Initiative brings local marine biota to classrooms and public events and demonstrates the tools and techniques that ocean scientists use to study the marine environment. The proposed molecular ecology laboratory and its outcomes will permit us to add this important element in the study of ocean science to the information that we share with public audiences. For more information about Shannon Point Marine Center, visit the web site at http://www.wwu.edu/spmc/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It has become standard to employ a variety of integrated methods, including molecular biology, in marine ecological research. Although the Shannon Point Marine Center’s (SPMC) facilities are equipped for world-class research and teaching that support a variety of methodological approaches, it has lacked the capacity to support molecular biological methods. This award filled this gap through development of the SPMC Marine Molecular Ecology and Environmental Genomic (MEEG) Labs, providing the capacity to extend and expand existing research at Western Washington University (WWU) to include molecular approaches to studying marine organisms and ecosystems. SPMC’s MEEG Labs provide resident and visiting scientists, as well as student researchers, the capacity to study genetic diversity in marine environments, evolutionary history of marine organisms, ecological function in the Salish Sea and other ocean systems, and the molecular mechanisms associated with responses to the environment.

This award supported the purchase of all equipment needed to go from sample collection to sequence analysis in a molecular ecology project. This includes pipettes, a PCR hood, real-time PCR system, thermocycler, Bioanalyzer for library quantification, and a high-throughput genome sequencer, among other accessory equipment. The keystone of this award and development of the SPMC MEEG Labs was the purchase of a benchtop genome sequencer (the Illumina MiSeq) with specifications that assure affordability and flexibility, and is currently the gold standard for generating sequences for small labs. This instrument allows for rapid turnaround of results that can support short-term student research projects, as well as quality data that supports the longer-term needs of faculty. A detailed description of the MEEG Labs, as well as additional information about SPMC’s facilities and programs, is available at www.wwu.edu/spmc.

In addition to setting up our new facilities, we have achieved a number of important milestones, including (1) enabling researchers to expand their current research capacity, (2) fostering cross-disciplinary collaboration, and (3) supporting WWU and SPMC missions.

A primary goal of development of these facilities was to allow WWU researchers to expand their research. Despite the fact that the facilities have been fully functional only within the last six months, SPMC-affiliated researchers, students, and early-career scientists have already begun adding molecular work to their research. New collaborations have formed, resulting in at least five new research proposals that integrate molecular work with traditional ecological methods at SPMC. Data generated from the MEEG Labs have already been presented at scientific meetings, resulted in one publication, and resulted in at least four publications projected for 2016. 

Another major goal of this facility was to increase cross-disciplinary collaborations at WWU and to attract collaborations from other institutions. Indeed, the addition of these advanced sequencing facilities makes SPMC rare among west coast marine labs, particularly those serving primarily undergraduate institutions. Thus far, the new capacity has engendered new collaborations between Western faculty members in the Biology, ESCI, and Computer Science departments, as well as within the Biology department. Moreover, the new facility has fostered collaborations between Western faculty and faculty at other regional primarily undergraduate institutions.

The MEEG Laboratories help to support the primary missions of WWU and SPMC. Part of WWU’s mission is to create an academic environment that combines the best of a large research institution with an intimate liberal arts college education.
